did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.abstract: The collection consists of eight letters to Dr. George S. Seymour, Litchfield, Conn., from his brother John and from Edward P. Cheney, both salesmen for the distribution of medical devices. Their letters discuss the splint business, travel hardships, freight problems, orders, and sales territory disputes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: There are eight letters, 1846-1847, written to Dr. George S. Seymour of Litchfield, Connecticut, by his brother John S. Seymour and E. P. Cheney, who were his salesmen for the distribution of medical devices, in Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee. The letters discuss the hardships of the travelling splint business due to road conditions, agents taking over salesmen's territories, freight problems, and financial issues. Included are some orders for splints, pelvic apparatus, and extensions. There are also strong requests for territorial rights by Cheney, Seymour, and Lockwood, especially for sections in Tennessee and Kentucky.
